author: mklement0
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Related: #14036

For syntactic convenience, PowerShell allows you to use _unquoted_ string keys in hashtables. 
If such an unquoted key can be parsed as a _number literal_, however, it is used as such (as a numeric type).

However, an unquoted key that _starts with a digit_ but cannot be interpreted as a number literal breaks hashtable literals, instead of falling back to interpreting it as a string:

```powershell
@{ 1a = 'one a' }
```

While `@{ '1a' = 'one a' }` is an easy workaround, it shouldn't be necessary.


### Expected behavior

```console
Name                           Value
----                           -----
1a                             one a
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The error quoted below occurs.
```


### Error details

```console
ParserError:
Line |
   1 |  @{ 1a = 'one a' }
     |    ~
     | Missing closing '}' in statement block or type definition.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.2.0-preview.8
```


### Visuals

_No response_

comments.author: JamesWTruher
comments.body:
this is also the case in PowerShell 5
```powershell
PS> $psversiontable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.17763.1971
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.17763.1971
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1


PS> @{1a = "one"}
At line:1 char:3
+ @{1a = "one"}
+   ~
The hash literal was incomplete.
At line:1 char:3
+ @{1a = "one"}
+   ~~
Unexpected token '1a' in expression or statement.
At line:1 char:13
+ @{1a = "one"}
+             ~
Unexpected token '}' in expression or statement.
    + CategoryInfo          : ParserError: (:) [], ParentContainsErrorRecordException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : IncompleteHashLiteral
```

comments.author: JamesWTruher
comments.body: WG agrees that this should probably work in the same way as other bareword keywords work.

title: An unquoted key that starts with a digit but isn't a number breaks hashtable literals
